topics.topic_name: DO ORGANISMS CREATE EXACT COPIES OF THEMSELVES?
key_concepts: We notice organisms because they reproduce.
Reproduction at its most basic level involves making copies of the blueprints of body design.
The chromosomes in the nucleus of a cell contain information for inheritance of features from parents to next generation in the form of DNA (Deoxyribo Nucleic Acid) molecules.
The DNA in the cell nucleus is the information source for making proteins.
A basic event in reproduction is the creation of a DNA copy.
Cells use chemical reactions to build copies of their DNA, creating two copies which then need to be separated.
DNA copying is accompanied by the creation of an additional cellular apparatus, and then the DNA copies separate, each with its own cellular apparatus.
Effectively, a cell divides to give rise to two cells.
The process of copying the DNA will have some variations each time because no bio-chemical reaction is absolutely reliable.
The DNA copies generated will be similar, but may not be identical to the original.
This inbuilt tendency for variation during reproduction is the basis for evolution.
Populations of organisms fill well-defined places, or niches, in the ecosystem, using their ability to reproduce.
The consistency of DNA copying is important for the maintenance of body design features that allow the organism to use a particular niche.
Reproduction is linked to the stability of populations of species.
If the niche of a population were drastically altered, the population could be wiped out.
If some variations were present in a few individuals, there would be some chance for them to survive.
Variation is useful for the survival of species over time (e.g., heat-resistant bacteria surviving increased water temperature).

topics.topic_name: MODES OF REPRODUCTION USED BY SINGLE ORGANISMS
key_concepts: The modes by which various organisms reproduce depend on the body design of the organisms.
For unicellular organisms, cell division, or **fission**, leads to the creation of new individuals.
Many bacteria and protozoa simply split into two equal halves during cell division.
In organisms such as Amoeba, the splitting of the two cells during division can take place in **any plane**.
In organisms like Leishmania (which cause kala-azar), **binary fission** occurs in a **definite orientation**.
Other single-celled organisms, such as the malarial parasite, **Plasmodium**, divide into many daughter cells simultaneously by **multiple fission**.
Yeast can put out small **buds** that separate and grow further.
In multi-cellular organisms with relatively simple body organisation (e.g., **Spirogyra**), the organism simply breaks up into smaller pieces (fragments) upon maturation.
These fragments grow into new individuals.
Multi-cellular organisms with complex body organization cannot simply divide cell-by-cell because their specialised cells are organized into tissues and organs.
Reproduction in complex multi-cellular organisms is the function of a **specific cell type** that is capable of growing, proliferating, and making other cell types.
Many fully differentiated organisms have the ability to give rise to new individual organisms from their body parts.
If the individual is cut or broken up into many pieces, many of these pieces grow into separate individuals.
Examples of organisms that can regenerate include simple animals like **Hydra and Planaria**.
**Regeneration** is the process where a piece grows into a complete organism.
Regeneration is carried out by **specialised cells** which proliferate and make large numbers of cells.
Regeneration is **not the same as reproduction**, since most organisms do not normally depend on being cut up to reproduce.
Organisms such as **Hydra** use regenerative cells for reproduction in the process of **budding**.
In Hydra, a bud develops as an outgrowth due to repeated cell division at one specific site.
The buds develop into tiny individuals, detach from the parent body when mature, and become new independent individuals.
**Vegetative propagation** is a mode of asexual reproduction in plants where parts like the root, stem, and leaves develop into new plants.
This property is used in methods like **layering or grafting** to grow plants such as sugarcane, roses, or grapes.
Plants raised by vegetative propagation can bear flowers and fruits **earlier** than those produced from seeds.
Vegetative propagation makes possible the propagation of plants (e.g., banana, orange, rose, jasmine) that have **lost the capacity to produce seeds**.
All plants produced by vegetative propagation are **genetically similar** to the parent plant.
Buds produced in the notches along the leaf margin of **Bryophyllum** fall on the soil and develop into new plants.
**Tissue culture** is a technique where new plants are grown by removing tissue or separating cells from the growing tip of a plant.
In tissue culture, cells form a **callus** (a small group of dividing cells) which is then transferred to a medium containing hormones for growth and differentiation.
Tissue culture allows many plants to be grown from one parent in **disease-free conditions** and is commonly used for **ornamental plants**.
Specific reproductive parts can be identified even in simple multi-cellular organisms like bread mould (**Rhizopus**).
The tiny blob-on-a-stick structures in Rhizopus are involved in reproduction.
The blobs are **sporangia**, which contain cells, or **spores**, that can develop into new individuals.
The spores are covered by thick walls that protect them until they come into contact with a moist surface.

All the modes discussed so far (fission, fragmentation, regeneration, budding, vegetative propagation, spore formation) are known as **asexual reproduction**, where new generations are created from a single individual.
Sexual reproduction depends on the involvement of two individuals (male and female) before a new generation can be created.

subtopics.subtopic_name: Why the Sexual Mode of Reproduction?
key_concepts: The sexual mode of reproduction allows **more and more variation** to be generated, which is useful for ensuring the survival of the species.
DNA-copying mechanisms are precise enough to make the generation of variation a fairly slow process.
Combining variations from two different individuals creates new, novel combinations of variants, **speeding up the process of making variants**.
Sexual reproduction incorporates a process of **combining DNA from two different individuals**.
A major difficulty of combining DNA is that each new generation would end up having **twice the amount of DNA**.
Multi-cellular organisms solve the DNA problem by having **special lineages of cells (germ-cells)** in specialised organs.
Germ-cells have **half the number of chromosomes and half the amount of DNA** compared to non-reproductive body cells.
The reduction of chromosome number is achieved by a process of cell division called **meiosis**.
When two germ-cells combine during sexual reproduction, it results in the **re-establishment of the number of chromosomes and the DNA content** in the new generation.
As body designs become more complex, germ-cells specialise: one is **large and contains food-stores (female gamete)**, and the other is **smaller and motile (male gamete)**.
The reproductive parts of angiosperms (flowering plants) are located in the **flower**.
**Stamens** and **pistil** are the reproductive parts that contain the germ-cells.
A flower may be **unisexual** (e.g., papaya, watermelon) containing either stamens or pistil, or **bisexual** (e.g., Hibiscus, mustard) containing both.
The **stamen** is the male reproductive part and produces **pollen grains**.

The **pistil** is the female reproductive part in the centre of a flower, made of the **ovary** (swollen bottom part), the **style** (middle elongated part), and the **stigma** (terminal sticky part).
The ovary contains **ovules**, and each ovule has an **egg cell** (female gamete).
**Fertilisation** is the fusion of the male germ-cell (from pollen) with the female gamete (in the ovule), which forms the **zygote**.
**Self-pollination** occurs if the transfer of pollen from stamen to stigma occurs in the same flower.
**Cross-pollination** occurs if the pollen is transferred from one flower to another, achieved by agents like wind, water, or animals.
After landing on the stigma, a **tube grows out of the pollen grain** and travels through the style to reach the ovary.
The zygote divides to form an **embryo** within the ovule.
The **ovule** develops a tough coat and is converted into a **seed**.
The **ovary** grows rapidly and ripens to form a **fruit**.
The **seed** contains the future plant or embryo, which develops into a seedling under appropriate conditions, a process known as **germination**.
Humans use a sexual mode of reproduction.
**Puberty** is the period during adolescence when the rate of general body growth begins to slow down, and reproductive tissues begin to mature.
Changes during puberty common to both boys and girls include growth of thick hair in armpits and the genital area, appearance of thinner hair on legs, arms, and face, oily skin, and pimples.
Changes specific to girls include increased breast size, darkening of nipples, and the onset of **menstruation**.
Changes specific to boys include new thick hair growth on the face, cracking of the voice, and occasional enlargement and erection of the penis.
These puberty changes are signals that **sexual maturation** is taking place.
The sexual mode requires germ-cells from two individuals to join, either externally (as in plants) or internally via **mating** (as in many animals).
The female reproductive organs and breasts need to mature to accommodate the possibility of carrying and breast-feeding a baby.
The formation of germ-cells or **sperms** takes place in the **testes**.
The testes are located outside the abdominal cavity in the **scrotum** because sperm formation requires a **lower temperature** than the normal body temperature.
Testosterone, secreted by the testes, regulates sperm formation and brings about changes in appearance seen in boys at puberty.
Sperms are delivered through the **vas deferens**, which unites with a tube from the urinary bladder.
The **urethra** forms a common passage for both sperms and urine.
Glands like the **prostate** and the **seminal vesicles** add their secretions to the sperms.
The fluid (semen) makes sperm transport easier and provides **nutrition** to the sperms.
Sperms are tiny bodies consisting mainly of **genetic material** and a **long tail** for movement.
The female germ-cells or **eggs** are made in the **ovaries**, which also produce some hormones.
Ovaries contain thousands of immature eggs at birth, and one egg starts maturing and is produced every month by one of the ovaries upon reaching puberty.
The egg is carried from the ovary to the womb through a thin **oviduct** or **fallopian tube**.
The two oviducts unite into an elastic bag-like structure known as the **uterus** (womb).
The uterus opens into the **vagina** through the **cervix**.
Sperms enter through the vaginal passage and travel upwards to the oviduct where they may encounter the egg.
The **fertilised egg (zygote)** starts dividing to form a ball of cells or **embryo**.
The embryo is **implanted in the lining of the uterus** where it grows and develops organs to become a **foetus**.
The lining of the uterus thickens and is richly supplied with blood every month to nourish the growing embryo.
The embryo gets nutrition from the mother’s blood with the help of a special tissue called **placenta**.
The **placenta** is a disc embedded in the uterine wall that provides a large surface area for glucose and oxygen to pass from the mother to the embryo.
Waste substances generated by the developing embryo are removed by transferring them into the mother’s blood through the placenta.
The development of the child inside the mother’s body takes approximately **nine months**.
The child is born as a result of rhythmic contractions of the muscles in the uterus.

subtopics.subtopic_name: 7.3.3 (c) What happens when the Egg is not Fertilised?
key_concepts: If the egg is not fertilised, it lives for about **one day**.
The uterus prepares itself every month to receive a fertilised egg by making its lining thick and spongy.
If fertilisation does not take place, the unneeded lining slowly breaks and comes out through the vagina as **blood and mucous**.
This cycle takes place roughly every month and is known as **menstruation**.
Menstruation usually lasts for about two to eight days.
Sexual maturation does not necessarily mean the body or mind is ready for sexual acts or for having and bringing up children.
Many diseases can be **sexually transmitted** (STDs) due to the intimate connection of bodies during the sexual act.
Bacterial STDs include **gonorrhoea and syphilis**; viral STDs include **warts and HIV-AIDS**.
Using a covering, called a **condom**, for the penis during sex helps to prevent transmission of many infections to some extent.
Contraceptive methods are devised to **avoid pregnancy**.
One category of contraceptive is the creation of a **mechanical barrier** so sperm does not reach the egg (e.g., condoms, vaginal coverings).
Another category acts by changing the **hormonal balance** of the body so that eggs are not released (e.g., oral pills), but these can cause side-effects.
Other contraceptive devices such as the **loop or the copper-T** are placed in the uterus to prevent pregnancy, but they can cause side effects due to irritation.
Surgical methods can be used to create blocks: blocking the **vas deferens** in males or the **fallopian tube** in females, preventing fertilisation.
Surgical methods used for removal of unwanted pregnancies can be misused for **illegal sex-selective abortion of female foetuses**.
For a healthy society, the **female-male sex ratio** must be maintained.
The size of the human population is a concern because an expanding population makes it harder to improve everybody’s standard of living.
Reproductive processes give rise to new individuals that are **similar, but subtly different**.
The number of successful variations is **maximised by the process of sexual reproduction**.
In asexually reproducing organisms (like sugarcane), very **little variation** is found.
In sexually reproducing organisms (like human beings), quite **distinct variations** are visible.
Inheritance from the previous generation provides both a **common basic body design** and **subtle changes** in it for the next generation.
In asexual reproduction (e.g., bacteria), differences are minor, generated due to **small inaccuracies in DNA copying**.
If sexual reproduction is involved, **even greater diversity** will be generated.
Different individuals have **different kinds of advantages** depending on the nature of their variations (e.g., bacteria that can withstand heat).
**Selection of variants by environmental factors** forms the basis for evolutionary processes.
The most obvious outcome of the reproductive process is the generation of individuals of similar design.
The **rules of heredity** determine the process by which traits and characteristics are reliably inherited.
A child bears all the basic features of a human being but does not look exactly like its parents.
Human populations show a great deal of variation.

subtopics.subtopic_name: Rules for the Inheritance of Traits – Mendel’s Contributions
key_concepts: Both the father and the mother contribute practically **equal amounts of genetic material** to the child.
Each trait in a child can be influenced by both paternal and maternal DNA, meaning there will be **two versions** for each trait.
**Gregor Mendel** worked out the main rules of inheritance using experiments with garden peas.
Mendel was the first to **keep count of individuals** exhibiting a particular trait in each generation, which helped him arrive at the laws of inheritance.
Mendel used a number of **contrasting visible characters** of pea plants (e.g., round/wrinkled seeds, tall/short plants).
In Mendel’s $	ext{F}_1$ progeny (crossing tall and short plants), there were **no halfway characteristics**; only one of the parental traits (tallness) was seen.

In the $	ext{F}_2$ progeny (self-pollination of $	ext{F}_1$ tall plants), one quarter of the plants were short, indicating both traits (tallness and shortness) were inherited in the $	ext{F}_1$ generation, but only tallness was **expressed**.
Mendel proposed that two copies of **factor (now called genes)** controlling traits are present in sexually reproducing organisms.
A single copy of the gene for tallness (**T**) is enough to make the plant tall (**Dominant Trait**).
Both copies of the gene must be for shortness (**t**) for the plant to be short (**Recessive Trait**).
When plants with two different characteristics (tall/round and short/wrinkled) are crossed, the $	ext{F}_1$ progeny are all **tall and have round seeds** (the dominant traits).
In the $	ext{F}_2$ generation of a dihybrid cross, new combinations appear (tall with wrinkled seeds and short with round seeds).
The tall/short trait and the round seed/wrinkled seed trait are **independently inherited**.

subtopics.subtopic_name: How do these Traits get Expressed?
key_concepts: Cellular DNA is the **information source for making proteins** in the cell.
A section of DNA that provides information for one protein is called the **gene** for that protein.
Traits are controlled by genes because the protein (e.g., an enzyme) made from the gene controls the process (e.g., hormone production) that leads to the characteristic (e.g., plant height).
To explain inheritance, it is assumed that **each parent contributes a copy of the same gene** and that each pea plant has **two sets of all genes**.
For this mechanism to work, each **germ cell must have only one gene set**.
Each gene set is present as separate independent pieces called **chromosomes**.
Every non-reproductive cell has **two copies of each chromosome** (one from the male parent and one from the female parent).
Every germ-cell takes **one chromosome from each pair** (either maternal or paternal origin).
When two germ cells combine (fertilisation), they restore the **normal number of chromosomes** in the progeny, ensuring the stability of the DNA of the species.
Sex determination strategies vary: some animals rely entirely on **environmental cues** (e.g., temperature for some reptiles).
In human beings, the sex of the individual is largely **genetically determined**.
Humans have **22 pairs of autosomes** (non-sex chromosomes) which are perfectly paired.
The **sex chromosomes** form the 23rd pair and are not always a perfect pair.
Women have a perfect pair of sex chromosomes, both called **X** ($	ext{XX}$).
Men have a mismatched pair: one **X** and one shorter chromosome called **Y** ($	ext{XY}$).
All children inherit an **X chromosome from their mother**.
The **sex of the children is determined by what they inherit from their father**.
Inheriting an $	ext{X}$ from the father results in a girl ($	ext{XX}$); inheriting a $	ext{Y}$ from the father results in a boy ($	ext{XY}$).
An object reflects light that falls on it, and this reflected light, when received by our eyes, enables us to see things.
Light seems to travel in **straight lines**, which is indicated by the fact that a small source of light casts a sharp shadow of an opaque object.
The straight-line path of light is usually indicated as a **ray of light**.
If an opaque object is very small, light has a tendency to bend around it, known as **diffraction of light**.
A **highly polished surface, such as a mirror**, reflects most of the light falling on it.
The **laws of reflection** are applicable to all types of reflecting surfaces, including spherical surfaces.
**Law (i):** The angle of incidence is equal to the angle of reflection.
**Law (ii):** The incident ray, the normal to the mirror at the point of incidence, and the reflected ray, all lie in the same plane.
The image formed by a **plane mirror** is always **virtual and erect**.
The size of the image formed by a plane mirror is **equal to that of the object**.
The image formed by a plane mirror is as far behind the mirror as the object is in front of it and is **laterally inverted**.
The most commonly used type of curved mirror is the **spherical mirror**.
A spherical mirror whose reflecting surface is **curved inwards** (faces towards the centre) is called a **concave mirror**.
A spherical mirror whose reflecting surface is **curved outwards** is called a **convex mirror**.
The centre of the reflecting surface of a spherical mirror is the **pole ($	ext{P}$)**.
The centre of the sphere of which the reflecting surface is a part is called the **centre of curvature ($	ext{C}$)**.
The centre of curvature lies **in front** of a concave mirror and **behind** a convex mirror.
The radius of the sphere is called the **radius of curvature ($	ext{R}$)**.
The imaginary straight line passing through the pole ($	ext{P}$) and the centre of curvature ($	ext{C}$) is called the **principal axis**.
The point where rays parallel to the principal axis meet (concave) or appear to diverge from (convex) after reflection is called the **principal focus ($	ext{F}$)**.
The distance between the pole ($	ext{P}$) and the principal focus ($	ext{F}$) is called the **focal length ($	ext{f}$)**.
The diameter of the reflecting surface is called its **aperture**.
For spherical mirrors of small apertures, the radius of curvature is equal to twice the focal length, expressed as **$	ext{R}=2	ext{f}$**.
This implies that the principal focus of a spherical mirror lies midway between the pole and centre of curvature.

The nature, position, and size of the image formed by a concave mirror depends on the **position of the object** in relation to $	ext{P}$, $	ext{F}$, and $	ext{C}$ (sometimes real, sometimes virtual, sometimes magnified, sometimes reduced).
A **convex mirror** gives a **virtual, erect, and diminished** image for all positions of the object.
A small convex mirror can give the **full image of a large object** (e.g., a tall building).

subtopics.subtopic_name: Representation of Images Formed by Spherical Mirrors Using Ray Diagrams
key_concepts: Image formation is studied by drawing ray diagrams, using only two specific rays for clarity.
**Ray (i):** A ray parallel to the principal axis, after reflection, passes through $	ext{F}$ (concave) or appears to diverge from $	ext{F}$ (convex).
**Ray (ii):** A ray passing through $	ext{F}$ (concave) or directed towards $	ext{F}$ (convex), after reflection, emerges **parallel** to the principal axis.

**Ray (iii):** A ray passing through $	ext{C}$ (concave) or directed towards $	ext{C}$ (convex), after reflection, is **reflected back along the same path** because it falls on the mirror along the normal.
**Ray (iv):** A ray incident obliquely to the principal axis at the pole ($	ext{P}$) is reflected obliquely, following the laws of reflection (angle of incidence = angle of reflection).

subtopics.subtopic_name: Sign Convention for Reflection by Spherical Mirrors
key_concepts: The **New Cartesian Sign Convention** is followed, with the **pole ($	ext{P}$) taken as the origin** and the principal axis as the x-axis.
The object is **always placed to the left** of the mirror, meaning light falls from the left-hand side.
All distances parallel to the principal axis are measured from the **pole ($	ext{P}$)**.
Distances measured to the **right** of the origin are taken as **positive** ($	ext{+x-axis}$).
Distances measured to the **left** of the origin are taken as **negative** ($	ext{-x-axis}$).
Distances measured **perpendicular to and above** the principal axis are taken as **positive** ($	ext{+y-axis}$).
Distances measured **perpendicular to and below** the principal axis are taken as **negative** ($	ext{-y-axis}$).
Object distance is ($	ext{u}$), image distance is ($	ext{v}$), and focal length is ($	ext{f}$), all measured from the pole.
The **Mirror Formula** relates these quantities: $$ rac{1}{v}+ rac{1}{u}= rac{1}{f}$$
**Magnification ($	ext{m}$)** gives the relative extent to which the image is magnified with respect to the object size.
Magnification is the ratio of the height of the image ($	ext{h'}$) to the height of the object ($	ext{h}$): $$m= rac{h'}{h}$$
Magnification is also related to the object and image distances: $$m=- rac{v}{u}$$
A **negative sign** in the value of $	ext{m}$ indicates that the image is **real**.
A **positive sign** in the value of $	ext{m}$ indicates that the image is **virtual**.
When light travels obliquely from one transparent medium to another, the direction of propagation of light in the second medium changes; this phenomenon is known as **refraction of light**.
The apparent raising of the bottom of a tank, the apparent displacement of a pencil in water, and letters appearing raised under a glass slab are all due to refraction.
The extent of the bending effect is **different for different pairs of media**.
Refraction is due to **change in the speed of light** as it enters from one transparent medium to another.
**Law (i):** The incident ray, the refracted ray and the normal to the interface, all lie in the same plane.

**Law (ii) (Snell's Law):** The ratio of sine of angle of incidence ($	ext{i}$) to the sine of angle of refraction ($	ext{r}$) is a constant for the light of a given colour and for the given pair of media: $$ rac{\sin i}{\sin r}=	ext{constant}$$
This constant value is called the **refractive index** of the second medium with respect to the first.

subtopics.subtopic_name: Refraction through a Rectangular Glass Slab
key_concepts: When a light ray enters from a **rarer medium to a denser medium** (e.g., air to glass), the ray **bends towards the normal**.
When a light ray enters from a **denser medium to a rarer medium** (e.g., glass to air), the ray **bends away from the normal**.
The emergent ray ($	ext{O'H}$) from a rectangular glass slab is **parallel to the direction of the incident ray** ($	ext{EO}$) because the bending at the two parallel faces is equal and opposite.
The light ray is shifted **sideward slightly** (lateral displacement).
The extent of the change in light direction is expressed in terms of the **refractive index ($	ext{n}$)**.
Light travels **fastest in vacuum** with speed $3 	imes 10^{8} 	ext{ m } 	ext{s}^{-1}$.

The refractive index of medium 2 with respect to medium 1 ($	ext{n}_{21}$) is the ratio of the speed of light in medium 1 ($	ext{v}_1$) to the speed of light in medium 2 ($	ext{v}_2$): $$n_{21} =  rac{v_1}{v_2}$$

The **absolute refractive index** ($	ext{n}_{	ext{m}}$) is the refractive index of a medium with respect to **vacuum or air**: $$n_m =  rac{	ext{Speed of light in air (c)}}{	ext{Speed of light in the medium (v)}}$$
The ability of a medium to refract light is expressed in terms of its **optical density**, which is **not the same as mass density**.
The medium with the **larger refractive index** is **optically denser**.
The speed of light is **higher in a rarer medium** than in a denser medium.
A **lens** is a transparent material bound by two surfaces, of which one or both are spherical.
A **convex lens** (thicker at the middle) is a **converging lens** because it converges light rays.
A **concave lens** (thicker at the edges) is a **diverging lens** because it diverges light rays.
A lens has **two centres of curvature ($	ext{C}_1$ and $	ext{C}_2$)**.
The imaginary straight line passing through the two centres of curvature is the **principal axis**.
The central point of a lens is its **optical centre ($	ext{O}$)**.
A ray of light through the **optical centre ($	ext{O}$) passes without suffering any deviation**.
A lens has **two principal foci ($	ext{F}_1$ and $	ext{F}_2$)**.
The distance of the principal focus from the optical centre is the **focal length ($	ext{f}$)**.
The nature, position, and relative size of the image formed by a **convex lens** depends on the position of the object (similar to a concave mirror).
A **concave lens** will **always** give a **virtual, erect, and diminished image**, irrespective of the position of the object.

subtopics.subtopic_name: Image Formation in Lenses Using Ray Diagrams
key_concepts: **Ray (i):** A ray parallel to the principal axis, after refraction, **passes through $	ext{F}$** (convex) or **appears to diverge from $	ext{F}$** (concave).
**Ray (ii):** A ray passing through $	ext{F}$ (convex) or appearing to meet at $	ext{F}$ (concave), after refraction, **emerges parallel** to the principal axis.
**Ray (iii):** A ray of light passing through the **optical centre ($	ext{O}$) will emerge without any deviation**.
For lenses, the sign convention is similar to mirrors, but **all measurements are taken from the optical centre ($	ext{O}$)**.
The focal length ($	ext{f}$) of a **convex lens is positive**.
The focal length ($	ext{f}$) of a **concave lens is negative**.
The **Lens Formula** relates the object distance ($	ext{u}$), image distance ($	ext{v}$), and focal length ($	ext{f}$): $$ rac{1}{v}- rac{1}{u}= rac{1}{f}$$
The magnification ($	ext{m}$) produced by a lens is the ratio of image height ($	ext{h'}$) to object height ($	ext{h}$): $$m= rac{h'}{h}$$
Magnification is also related to the distances: $$m= rac{v}{u}$$
The **power ($	ext{P}$) of a lens** expresses its degree of convergence or divergence of light rays.
The power of a lens is defined as the **reciprocal of its focal length ($	ext{f}$)**: $$P= rac{1}{f}$$
The **SI unit of power** of a lens is **dioptre ($	ext{D}$)**, where $1	ext{ D} = 1	ext{ m}^{-1}$ (if $	ext{f}$ is expressed in metres).
The power ($	ext{P}$) of a **convex lens is positive**.
The power ($	ext{P}$) of a **concave lens is negative**.
The net power of lenses placed in contact is the algebraic sum of the individual powers: $	ext{P} = 	ext{P}_1 + 	ext{P}_2 + 	ext{P}_3 + \dots$

chapter_name: The Human Eye and the Colourful World

key_concepts: The human eye is one of the most valuable and sensitive sense organs, enabling us to see the world and colours around us.
The human eye is like a **camera**.
The eye's lens system forms an image on a light-sensitive screen called the **retina**.
Light enters the eye through a thin membrane called the **cornea**.
The cornea forms the **transparent bulge** on the front surface of the eyeball.
The eyeball is approximately spherical with a diameter of about **2.3 cm**.
Most of the **refraction** for the light rays entering the eye occurs at the **outer surface of the cornea**.
The **crystalline lens** provides the **finer adjustment of focal length** required to focus objects at different distances on the retina.
The **iris** is a dark muscular diaphragm behind the cornea that **controls the size of the pupil**.
The **pupil** regulates and controls the **amount of light entering the eye**.
The eye lens forms an **inverted real image** of the object on the retina.
The retina is a delicate membrane with an enormous number of **light-sensitive cells**.
Light-sensitive cells get activated upon illumination, generate **electrical signals**, which are sent to the brain via the **optic nerves**.
The eye lens is composed of a fibrous, jelly-like material whose curvature can be modified by the **ciliary muscles**.
The change in the curvature of the eye lens changes its **focal length**.
When the ciliary muscles are relaxed, the lens becomes thin, its focal length increases, enabling us to see **distant objects clearly**.
When the ciliary muscles contract, the lens becomes thicker, its focal length decreases, enabling us to see **nearby objects clearly**.
The ability of the eye lens to adjust its focal length is called **accommodation**.
The minimum distance, at which objects can be seen most distinctly without strain, is called the **least distance of distinct vision** or the **near point**.
For a young adult with normal vision, the near point is about **25 cm**.
The farthest point up to which the eye can see objects clearly is called the **far point**, which is **infinity** for a normal eye.
A normal eye can see objects clearly that are between **25 cm and infinity**.
**Cataract** is a condition where the crystalline lens becomes milky and cloudy, causing partial or complete loss of vision, which can be restored through surgery.

topics.topic_name: DEFECTS OF VISION AND THEIR CORRECTION
key_concepts: The three common refractive defects of vision are **myopia (near-sightedness)**, **hypermetropia (far-sightedness)**, and **presbyopia**.
These defects can be corrected by the use of **suitable spherical lenses**.
**Myopia** is also known as near-sightedness.
A person with myopia can see **nearby objects clearly** but **cannot see distant objects distinctly**.
The image of a distant object is formed **in front of the retina** in a myopic eye.
Myopia arises due to **(i) excessive curvature of the eye lens** or **(ii) elongation of the eyeball**.
This defect is corrected by using a **concave lens** of suitable power.
**Hypermetropia** is also known as far-sightedness.
A person with hypermetropia can see **distant objects clearly** but **cannot see nearby objects distinctly**.
The near point is farther away from the normal near point (25 cm).
The light rays from a close object are focussed at a point **behind the retina**.
Hypermetropia arises either because **(i) the focal length of the eye lens is too long** or **(ii) the eyeball has become too small**.
This defect is corrected by using a **convex lens (converging lenses)** of appropriate power.
**Presbyopia** is the defect where the power of accommodation decreases with ageing, making it difficult to see nearby objects.
It arises due to the **gradual weakening of the ciliary muscles** and the **diminishing flexibility of the eye lens**.
People suffering from both myopia and hypermetropia often require **bi-focal lenses**.
Bi-focal lenses consist of a **concave lens in the upper portion** (for distant vision) and a **convex lens in the lower part** (for near vision).

topics.topic_name: REFRACTION OF LIGHT THROUGH A PRISM
key_concepts: A triangular glass prism has two triangular bases and three rectangular lateral surfaces that are inclined to each other.
The angle between the two lateral faces of a prism is called the **angle of the prism**.
When light enters from air to glass at the first surface, it **bends towards the normal**.
When light enters from glass to air at the second surface, it **bends away from the normal**.
The peculiar shape of the prism makes the emergent ray bend at an angle to the direction of the incident ray.
The angle between the incident ray and the emergent ray is called the **angle of deviation ($\angle	ext{D}$)**.

topics.topic_name: DISPERSION OF WHITE LIGHT BY A GLASS PRISM
key_concepts: The band of the coloured components of a light beam is called its **spectrum**.
The spectrum of white light contains the sequence of colours: **Violet, Indigo, Blue, Green, Yellow, Orange, and Red (VIBGYOR)**.
The **dispersion** of light is the **splitting of light into its component colours**.
White light is dispersed into seven-colour components by a prism because **different colours of light bend through different angles** as they pass through.
The **red light bends the least** while the **violet light bends the most**.
**Isaac Newton** was the first to obtain the spectrum of sunlight using a glass prism.
Newton demonstrated that sunlight is made up of seven colours by using a second, identical, **inverted prism** to recombine the spectrum back into **white light**.
A **rainbow** is a natural spectrum caused by **dispersion of sunlight by tiny water droplets** in the atmosphere.
A rainbow is always formed in a direction **opposite to that of the Sun**.
Water droplets act like small prisms: they **refract, disperse, reflect internally, and then refract again** when light comes out.
**Atmospheric refraction** is the refraction of light by the earth's atmosphere.
Hot air is **lighter (less dense)** than cooler air and has a **refractive index slightly less** than cooler air.
The random wavering or flickering of objects seen through turbulent hot air is an effect of atmospheric refraction.
The **twinkling of stars** is due to atmospheric refraction of starlight on a larger scale.
The atmosphere bends starlight **towards the normal**, making the **apparent position of the star slightly higher** than its actual position near the horizon.
The apparent position of a star fluctuates because the **physical conditions of the earth's atmosphere are not stationary**.
Planets do not twinkle because they are much **closer to the earth** and are seen as **extended sources** (collections of point-sized sources).
Atmospheric refraction causes the Sun to be visible about **2 minutes before the actual sunrise** and about **2 minutes after the actual sunset**.
The interplay of light with objects gives rise to phenomena like the blue colour of the sky, the colour of deep sea water, and the reddening of the sun at sunrise/sunset.
The earth's atmosphere is a **heterogeneous mixture** of minute particles (smoke, water droplets, dust, air molecules).
When a beam of light strikes these fine particles, the **path of the beam becomes visible**.
The light reaches us after being **reflected diffusely** by these particles.
The phenomenon of **scattering of light by colloidal particles** is called the **Tyndall effect**.
The **colour of the scattered light depends on the size** of the scattering particles.
**Very fine particles scatter mainly blue light** (shorter wavelengths).
**Larger particles scatter light of longer wavelengths**, and if the size is large enough, the scattered light appears white.

subtopics.subtopic_name: Why is the colour of the clear Sky Blue?
key_concepts: Molecules of air and fine particles are **smaller than the wavelength of visible light**.
They are more effective in scattering light of **shorter wavelengths (blue end)** than light of longer wavelengths (red end).
The **red light has a wavelength about 1.8 times greater than blue light**.
When sunlight passes through the atmosphere, the fine particles scatter the blue colour more strongly, and this scattered blue light enters our eyes.
If the earth had no atmosphere, there would be no scattering, and the sky would look **dark**.
The sky appears dark to passengers flying at **very high altitudes** because scattering is not prominent there.
'Danger' signal lights are **red** because red is **least scattered by fog or smoke** and can be seen in the same colour at a distance.
If the electric charge flows through a conductor (e.g., a metallic wire), there is an **electric current** in the conductor.
An electric current is the **rate of flow of electric charges**.
In circuits using metallic wires, **electrons** constitute the flow of charges.
A **continuous and closed path** of an electric current is called an **electric circuit**.
Conventionally, the direction of electric current is taken as **opposite to the direction of the flow of electrons** (negative charges).
If a net charge $	ext{Q}$, flows across a conductor in time $	ext{t}$, the current $	ext{I}$ is given by: $$I=\frac{Q}{t}$$
The **SI unit of electric charge is coulomb ($	ext{C}$)**.
One coulomb is equivalent to the charge contained in nearly $6\times10^{18}$ electrons.
The **electric current is expressed by a unit called ampere ($	ext{A}$)**.
One ampere is constituted by the flow of **one coulomb of charge per second** ($1	ext{ A}=1	ext{ C}/1	ext{ s}$ ).
An instrument called **ammeter** measures electric current and is always connected in **series** in a circuit.
Electric current flows in the circuit from the **positive terminal** of the cell to the **negative terminal**.
Electrons move only if there is a difference of electric pressure, called the **potential difference**, along the conductor.
A **battery** (consisting of one or more electric cells) produces the potential difference.
The chemical action within a cell generates the potential difference across its terminals.
**Electric potential difference ($	ext{V}$) is defined as the work done ($	ext{W}$) to move a unit charge ($	ext{Q}$) from one point to the other**.
The **SI unit of electric potential difference is volt ($	ext{V}$)**.
One volt is the potential difference when **1 joule ($	ext{J}$) of work** is done to move a charge of **1 coulomb ($	ext{C}$)** ($1	ext{ V}=1	ext{ J}	ext{ C}^{-1}$ ).
The potential difference is measured by an instrument called the **voltmeter**.
The voltmeter is always connected in **parallel** across the points between which the potential difference is to be measured.
A schematic diagram is used to represent an electric circuit, where different components are represented by conventional symbols (e.g., cell, battery, key, resistor, ammeter, voltmeter).

**Ohm's Law:** The potential difference ($	ext{V}$) across the ends of a metallic wire is **directly proportional to the current ($	ext{I}$) flowing through it**, provided its temperature remains the same.
$$V\propto I$$ or $$V=IR$$
$	ext{R}$ is a constant for a given metallic wire at a given temperature and is called its **resistance**.
**Resistance ($	ext{R}$)** is the property of a conductor to **resist the flow of charges** through it.
The **SI unit of resistance is ohm ($\Omega$)**.
$$R=V/I$$ (1 ohm = 1 volt / 1 ampere)
The current ($	ext{I}$) through a resistor is **inversely proportional to its resistance** ($I=V/R$).
A component used to regulate current without changing the voltage source is called **variable resistance**.
A device called **rheostat** is often used to change the resistance in a circuit.
Motion of electrons through a conductor is retarded by its resistance due to attraction from the atoms.
A component offering **low resistance** is a **good conductor**; one offering an **appreciable resistance** is called a **resistor**.

topics.topic_name: FACTORS ON WHICH THE RESISTANCE OF A CONDUCTOR DEPENDS
key_concepts: The resistance ($	ext{R}$) of a conductor depends on: **(i) its length ($	ext{l}$)**, **(ii) its area of cross-section ($	ext{A}$)**, and **(iii) the nature of its material**.
Resistance ($	ext{R}$) is **directly proportional to its length ($	ext{l}$)** ($	ext{R} \propto l$).
Resistance ($	ext{R}$) is **inversely proportional to the area of cross-section ($	ext{A}$)** ($	ext{R} \propto 1/A$).
The relationship is given by: $$R=\rho\frac{l}{A}$$
$ho$ (rho) is the constant of proportionality called the **electrical resistivity** of the material.
The **SI unit of resistivity is $\Omega	ext{ m}$**.
Metals and alloys have **very low resistivity** ($10^{-8}\ \Omega	ext{m}$ to $10^{-6}\ \Omega	ext{m}$) and are **good conductors**.
Insulators (e.g., rubber, glass) have **high resistivity** ($10^{12}\ \Omega	ext{m}$ to $10^{17}\ \Omega	ext{m}$).
The resistivity of an alloy is generally **higher** than that of its constituent metals.
Alloys are commonly used in electrical heating devices (e.g., electric iron, toasters) because they **do not oxidise (burn) readily at high temperatures**.
Tungsten is used for **filaments of electric bulbs** because of its high melting point.

topics.topic_name: RESISTANCE OF A SYSTEM OF RESISTORS
key_concepts: Resistors can be joined in two ways: **series** (joined end to end) or **parallel** (connected together between two common points).
In a series combination, the **current ($	ext{I}$) is the same** in every part of the circuit and through each resistor.
The **total potential difference ($	ext{V}$) is equal to the sum of the potential differences** across the individual resistors: $$V=V_1+V_2+V_3$$
The equivalent resistance of the combination ($	ext{R}_{	ext{s}}$) equals the **sum of their individual resistances** ($R_1, R_2, R_3$): $$R_s=R_1+R_2+R_3$$
The equivalent resistance in a series combination is **greater than any individual resistance**.
In a parallel combination, the **total current ($	ext{I}$) is equal to the sum of the separate currents** through each branch: $$I=I_1+I_2+I_3$$

The **reciprocal of the equivalent resistance ($	ext{R}_{	ext{p}}$)** is equal to the **sum of the reciprocals of the individual resistances** ($R_1, R_2, R_3$): $$\frac{1}{R_p}=\frac{1}{R_1}+\frac{1}{R_2}+\frac{1}{R_3}$$
The potential difference ($	ext{V}$) across each resistor in a parallel combination is the same.
To maintain current, the energy source (battery) has to keep expending its energy.
When the electric circuit is **purely resistive**, the source energy continually gets dissipated **entirely in the form of heat**.
This dissipation is known as the **heating effect of electric current**.
The amount of heat ($	ext{H}$) produced in time $	ext{t}$ is given by: $$H=VIt$$
Applying Ohm's law, the heat produced is: $$H=I^2Rt$$
This is known as **Joule's law of heating**.

Joule's law implies that heat produced ($	ext{H}$) is directly proportional to: **(i) the square of current ($	ext{I}^2$)**, **(ii) the resistance ($	ext{R}$)**, and **(iii) the time ($	ext{t}$)** for which the current flows.

subtopics.subtopic_name: Practical Applications of Heating Effect of Electric Current
key_concepts: The heating effect is utilised in devices like the **electric iron, toaster, electric oven, electric kettle, and electric heater**.
In an electric bulb, the filament must retain heat to get very hot and emit light; a strong metal with a **high melting point, such as tungsten ($3380^{\circ}	ext{C}$),** is used for the filament.
Electric bulbs are usually filled with chemically inactive **nitrogen and argon gases** to prolong the life of the filament.
Another common application is the **fuse**, which protects circuits and appliances by stopping the flow of unduly high electric current.
The fuse is placed in **series** with the device.
A fuse consists of a wire made of a metal or alloy (e.g., aluminium, copper, lead) with an **appropriate melting point**.
If the current is too high, the fuse wire melts and breaks the circuit.
**Electric power ($	ext{P}$)** is the **rate of consumption of electric energy** or the rate at which electric energy is dissipated.
Power ($	ext{P}$) is given by: $$P=VI$$ or $$P=I^2R=\frac{V^2}{R}$$
The **SI unit of electric power is watt ($	ext{W}$)**.
One watt is the power consumed by a device carrying $	ext{1 A}$ of current at $	ext{1 V}$ potential difference ($1	ext{ W}=1	ext{ VA}$ ).
The commercial unit of electric energy is the **kilowatt hour ($	ext{kWh}$)**, commonly known as a **'unit'**.
$$1	ext{ kWh} = 3.6\times10^{6} 	ext{ joule } (	ext{J})$$.
An electric current-carrying wire **behaves like a magnet** (produces a magnetic effect).

**Hans Christian Oersted** discovered that a compass needle got deflected when an electric current passed through a metallic wire placed nearby, showing that electricity and magnetism were related phenomena.
A compass needle is a **small bar magnet**.
The end of a compass needle pointing North is the **North seeking or North pole**.
The end of a compass needle pointing South is the **South seeking or South pole**.
**Like poles repel**, while **unlike poles attract** each other.
The **magnetic field** is the region surrounding a magnet in which the force of the magnet can be detected.
The lines along which iron filings align themselves represent **magnetic field lines**.
Magnetic field is a quantity that has both **direction and magnitude**.
By convention, the magnetic field lines **emerge from the north pole and merge at the south pole** outside the magnet.
Inside the magnet, the direction of field lines is from its **south pole to its north pole**.
Thus, the magnetic field lines are **closed curves**.
The **relative strength** of the magnetic field is shown by the **degree of closeness** of the field lines.
The field is stronger where the field lines are **crowded**.
**No two field-lines are found to cross each other**.

topics.topic_name: MAGNETIC FIELD DUE TO A CURRENT-CARRYING CONDUCTOR
key_concepts: An electric current through a metallic conductor produces a magnetic field around it.
The **direction of the magnetic field** produced is **reversed** when the direction of the electric current is reversed.

subtopics.subtopic_name: Magnetic Field due to a Current through a Straight Conductor
key_concepts: The pattern of the magnetic field around a current-carrying straight wire consists of **concentric circles** centered on the wire.
The **magnitude of the magnetic field** produced at a given point **increases as the current through the wire increases**.
The **magnetic field decreases as the distance from the conductor increases**.
The concentric circles representing the magnetic field become **larger and larger** as we move away from the wire.
The **Right-Hand Thumb Rule** is a convenient way of finding the direction of the magnetic field associated with a current-carrying straight conductor.
If you hold the conductor in your right hand with the **thumb pointing towards the direction of current**.
Then your **fingers will wrap around the conductor in the direction of the magnetic field lines**.

subtopics.subtopic_name: Magnetic Field due to a Current through a Circular Loop
key_concepts: At every point of a current-carrying circular loop, the concentric circles representing the magnetic field become larger and larger as one moves away from the wire.
At the **centre of the circular loop**, the arcs of these big circles appear as **straight lines**.
Every section of the wire contributes to the magnetic field lines **in the same direction** within the loop.

subtopics.subtopic_name: Magnetic Field due to a Current in a Solenoid
key_concepts: A **solenoid** is a coil of many circular turns of insulated copper wire wrapped closely in the shape of a cylinder.
The pattern of the magnetic field lines around a current-carrying solenoid is **similar to that of a bar magnet**.
One end of the solenoid behaves as a magnetic **north pole** and the other as the **south pole**.
The field lines **inside the solenoid are parallel straight lines**, indicating that the magnetic field is **uniform** inside the solenoid.
A strong magnetic field produced inside a solenoid can be used to magnetise a piece of magnetic material, like soft iron, to form an **electromagnet**.

topics.topic_name: FORCE ON A CURRENT-CARRYING CONDUCTOR IN A MAGNETIC FIELD
key_concepts: A magnetic field produced by a current-carrying conductor exerts a force on a magnet placed nearby.
The magnet must also exert an **equal and opposite force on the current-carrying conductor**.
A force is exerted on a current-carrying conductor when it is **placed in a magnetic field**.
The direction of the force is **reversed** when the **direction of current is reversed** or when the **direction of the magnetic field is reversed**.
The direction of the force depends upon the **direction of current and the direction of the magnetic field**.
The magnitude of the force is the **highest (largest)** when the direction of current is **at right angles** ($90^{\circ}$) to the direction of the magnetic field.
**Fleming's Left-Hand Rule** is a simple rule to find the direction of the force on a current-carrying conductor when the current and magnetic field are perpendicular.
Stretch the **thumb, forefinger, and middle finger** of your left hand such that they are **mutually perpendicular**.
If the **forefinger** points in the direction of the **Magnetic Field**.
And the **middle finger** points in the direction of the **Current**.
Then the **thumb** will point in the direction of **Motion or the Force** acting on the conductor.
Devices that use current-carrying conductors and magnetic fields include the **electric motor, electric generator, loudspeakers, microphones and measuring instruments**.
In domestic circuits, the **live wire** (or positive) usually has **red insulation** cover.
The **neutral wire** (or negative) has **black insulation**.
In India, the potential difference between the live and neutral wires is **220 V**.
There are often two separate domestic circuits: one of **15 A** rating (for high-power appliances like geysers), and another of **5 A** rating (for low-power appliances like bulbs/fans).
The **earth wire** has **green insulation** and is connected to a metal plate deep in the earth as a safety measure.

The metallic body of an appliance (e.g., iron, toaster) is connected to the earth wire, providing a **low-resistance conducting path** for leakage current to prevent the user from getting a severe electric shock.
Domestic appliances are connected in **parallel** to each other so that each appliance has **equal potential difference**.
**Overloading** occurs when the current in the circuit abruptly increases.
**Short-circuiting** occurs when the live wire and the neutral wire come into direct contact (due to damaged insulation or a fault).
The **electric fuse** prevents damage to appliances and the circuit by stopping the flow of unduly high electric current by **melting due to Joule heating**.
All the interacting organisms in an area together with the non-living constituents of the environment form an **ecosystem**.

An ecosystem consists of **biotic components** (living organisms like plants, animals, microorganisms, human beings) and **abiotic components** (physical factors like temperature, rainfall, wind, soil, and minerals).
**Natural ecosystems** are forests, ponds, and lakes.
**Human-made (artificial) ecosystems** are gardens and crop-fields.
**Producers** are organisms (all green plants and certain bacteria) that make organic compounds (food) from inorganic substances using the radiant energy of the Sun through photosynthesis.
**Consumers** are organisms that depend on producers either directly or indirectly for their sustenance.
Consumers can be classed as **herbivores, carnivores, omnivores, and parasites**.
**Decomposers** are microorganisms, comprising bacteria and fungi, that break-down the dead remains and waste products of organisms.
Decomposers break-down complex organic substances into simple inorganic substances that go into the soil and are used up once more by plants.
A **food chain** is a series of organisms feeding on one another.
Each step or level of the food chain forms a **trophic level**.
**Autotrophs (producers)** are at the **first trophic level**.
**Herbivores (primary consumers)** are at the **second trophic level**.
**Small carnivores (secondary consumers)** are at the **third trophic level**.
**Larger carnivores (tertiary consumers)** form the **fourth trophic level**.
The flow of energy between various components of the environment is **unidirectional**.
Green plants capture about **1% of the energy of sunlight** that falls on their leaves and convert it into food energy.
An average of **10% of the food eaten** is turned into its own body and made available for the next level of consumers (the **10% law**).
Food chains generally consist of **only three or four steps** because the loss of usable energy at each step is very great.
There are generally a **greater number of individuals at the lower trophic levels** of an ecosystem (the greatest number is of the producers).
A **food web** is a series of branching lines that shows the complex relationships where one organism is generally eaten by two or more other kinds of organisms.
**Biological magnification** is the phenomenon where non-degradable chemicals (like pesticides) get accumulated progressively at each trophic level.
As human beings occupy the top level in any food chain, the **maximum concentration of these chemicals gets accumulated in our bodies**.

topics.topic_name: HOW DO OUR ACTIVITIES AFFECT THE ENVIRONMENT?
key_concepts: We are an integral part of the environment; changes in the environment affect us, and our activities change the environment.
Two major environmental problems are the **depletion of the ozone layer** and **waste disposal**.

subtopics.subtopic_name: Ozone Layer and How it is Getting Depleted
key_concepts: **Ozone ($	ext{O}_3$)** is a molecule formed by three atoms of oxygen.
At the higher levels of the atmosphere, ozone performs the essential function of **shielding the surface of the earth from ultraviolet ($	ext{UV}$) radiation** from the Sun.
UV radiation is highly damaging to organisms (e.g., known to cause **skin cancer** in humans).

Ozone is formed at higher atmospheric levels by UV radiation splitting molecular oxygen ($	ext{O}_2$) into free oxygen ($	ext{O}$) atoms, which then combine with molecular oxygen: $	ext{UV}\ O_2ightarrow 	ext{O}+	ext{O}$; $	ext{O}+	ext{O}_2ightarrow 	ext{O}_3\ 	ext{(Ozone)}$
The ozone amount began to drop sharply in the 1980s, linked to synthetic chemicals like **chlorofluorocarbons ($	ext{CFCs}$)**.
$	ext{CFCs}$ are used as **refrigerants** and in **fire extinguishers**.
In 1987, the **United Nations Environment Programme (UNEP)** forged an agreement to freeze $	ext{CFC}$ production at 1986 levels.
It is now mandatory for all manufacturing companies to make **CFC-free refrigerators** throughout the world.
**Enzymes are specific in their action**; specific enzymes are needed for the break-down of a particular substance.
Many human-made materials like **plastics will not be broken down** by the action of bacteria or other saprophytes.
Substances that are broken down by biological processes are said to be **biodegradable**.
Substances that are not broken down by biological processes are said to be **non-biodegradable**.
Non-biodegradable substances persist for a long time in the environment or may harm members of the ecosystem.
Improvements in our life-style have resulted in **greater amounts of waste material generation**.
Changes in packaging have resulted in much of our waste becoming **non-biodegradable**.
